abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            unsatisfactory, though sustainability is likely, with
            substantial institutional development impacts, and, despite
            inadequate Bank support during the first four years of
            implementation, its performance is rated marginally
            satisfactory, while the borrower's performance is rated
            satisfactory, given its ability to overcome disbursement
            delays, and channeling of funds to communities, and line
            ministries. Lessons address five broad categories: 1)
            Project experience demonstrated that although
            nongovernmental organizations, and associations do hold an
            intimate knowledge of local communities, and in dealing with
            beneficiaries, they have limited technical, financial
            management, and monitoring and evaluation capacities. Thus,
            competitive processes to award contracts should be promoted,
            performance indicators strengthened, and monitoring criteria
            adapted. 2) The community driven approach, and pace should
            be adapted to the local socio-cultural context, focused on
            care, and treatment of HIV/AIDS. 3) Behavioral change is
            more likely to occur if preventive messages are accompanied
            by genuine changes in gender dynamics, i.e., changes that
            empower women to better control their sexuality, while
            multi-sectoral common goals should transcend institutional
            boundaries. 4) Performance indicators should be selected to
            achieve program goals, and objectives, within realistic
            targets, by assessing institutional arrangements capable of
            handling monitoring and evaluation. 5) Flexible procedures
            should be adopted for channeling funds, to improve
            accountability, raise motivation, and accelerate the pace of implementation.
